content.description: Climb into a low angle, right-facing corner and at the top cut left up a crack with knobs.
content.protection: Gear to 3 inches including the belay
content.location:
Right of

Absolutely Slabulous

on the edge of the smooth face.

content.description: Thin and delicate face problem between the two bolted lines.
content.location:
The smooth face between

Carlos

and

Absolutely Slabulous

.

content.description:
This climbs the obvious crack/gully on the left side of the slabby face.

Mistakenly referred to as "Pedro" in the 2004 Hidden Valley Guidebook by Alan Bartlett.
content.protection: Gear to 3 inches, fat pine tree for the anchor
content.location:
Just left of

Carlos

on the edge of the smooth slab and behind a pine tree.

content.description: Start on easy moves in to the dimple of the wall towards a shallow 3 finger pocket crux is getting out of the dimple and start the slab climb.
content.protection: Scrabble from the left or lead or solo Pine-sol, build anchor with a long static line around the dinosaur head and crack to the right of it can fit a purple, red, and yellow BD cams.
content.location: A few feet to the left of Pine-sol.

climbs.name: The Gift of Slab
climbs.fa: (TR) Chris Miller, January 1999; First Lead: Dave Carrera

content.description:
Start up

Solo-Angle Dihedral

and then cut left via cracks and finish on the slabby arÃªte.
content.location:
Just right of

Absolutely Slabulous

on the right margin of the slabby face.

content.description: This climbs the right of two parallel roof cracks formed by a block that dropped away. Short but engaging.
content.location:
Located up and right from

Absolutely Slabulous

and obvious on the walk-off from that route or Carlos.

content.description: This climbs the left of two parallel roof cracks formed by a block that dropped away. Short but engaging.
content.location:
Located up and right from

Absolutely Slabulous

and obvious on the walk-off from that route or Carlos.

climbs.name: Carlos
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon and Cyndie Bransford, May 1994

content.description:
A short but fun slab on good rock in a remote-feeling area, although only minutes from the car - something worth seeking out on those busy weekends.

This, the left and more difficult of the two slab routes here, climbs a brown slab with thin edges and smears. Take gear to belay or tie off the tree above the routes.

Walk/scramble off to the left or right.
content.protection: 3 bolts, gear to 3 inches for the anchor or use the tree
content.location:
West face of the rock just left of

Absolutely Slabulous

. Walk left past

Coarse and Buggy

and through a rocky notch between Dihedral Rock and Glory Rock; once through the notch head right to the base of this west-facing slab.

content.description:
This is the companion route to Carlos and lies just to the right of that line on the same section of rock.

Well-protected slab moves are to be expected with moves that are a touch easier than the neighboring line. Gear belay and walk-off.
content.protection: 3 bolts (3/8"), gear to 3 inches for the anchor
content.location:
Right of

Carlos

on the smooth west-facing slab.
